rlOspf.name: rlOspf
rlOspf.description: The private MIB module definition for Multi Instance OSPF MIB.

RlOspfFastHelloMultiplierRange.name: RlOspfFastHelloMultiplierRange
RlOspfFastHelloMultiplierRange.description: The range of hello multipliers that determine how often Fast Hellos are exchanged.

RlOspfRestartHelperStatus.name: RlOspfRestartHelperStatus
RlOspfRestartHelperStatus.description: Indicates whether the router is acting as a hitless restart helper for a neighbor.

RlOspfRestartExitReason.name: RlOspfRestartExitReason
RlOspfRestartExitReason.description: The reason for exiting an attempted graceful restart.

RlOspfRouterIdType.name: RlOspfRouterIdType
RlOspfRouterIdType.description: The reason for exiting an attempted graceful restart.

RlOspfUpToRefreshIntervalTC.name: RlOspfUpToRefreshIntervalTC
RlOspfUpToRefreshIntervalTC.description: The values one might be able to configure for variables bounded by the Refresh Interval.
RlOspfUpToRefreshIntervalTC.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix B, Architectural Constants

RlOspfDeadIntervalRangeTC.name: RlOspfDeadIntervalRangeTC
RlOspfDeadIntervalRangeTC.description: The range, in seconds, of dead interval value.
RlOspfDeadIntervalRangeTC.reference: OSPF for IPv6, Appendix C.3, Router Interface Parameters

rlOspfInstance.name: rlOspfInstance
rlOspfInstance.description: Selected OSPF Process ID. Additional key value for old fashion usage of OSPF standard MIB to support multi OSPF instance.

rlOspfGeneralGroupEntry.name: rlOspfGeneralGroupEntry
rlOspfGeneralGroupEntry.description: Information describing the configured global parame- ters to the Router OSPF Process.

rlOspfProcessId.name: rlOspfProcessId
rlOspfProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfRouterId.name: rlOspfRouterId
rlOspfRouterId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the router in the Autonomous System. By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this should default to the value of one of the router's IP interface addresses. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfAdminStat.name: rlOspfAdminStat
rlOspfAdminStat.description: The administrative status of OSPF in the router. The value 'enabled' denotes that the OSPF Process is active on at least one interface; 'disabled' disables it on all interfaces. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfVersionNumber.name: rlOspfVersionNumber
rlOspfVersionNumber.description: The current version number of the OSPF protocol is 2.

rlOspfAreaBdrRtrStatus.name: rlOspfAreaBdrRtrStatus
rlOspfAreaBdrRtrStatus.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 3 Splitting the AS into Areas
rlOspfAreaBdrRtrStatus.description: A flag to note whether this router is an Area Border Router.

rlOspfASBdrRtrStatus.name: rlOspfASBdrRtrStatus
rlOspfASBdrRtrStatus.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 3.3 Classification of routers
rlOspfASBdrRtrStatus.description: A flag to note whether this router is configured as an Autonomous System Border Router. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfExternLsaCount.name: rlOspfExternLsaCount
rlOspfExternLsaCount.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.5 AS external link advertisements
rlOspfExternLsaCount.description: The number of external (LS type-5) link state advertisements in the link state database.

rlOspfExternLsaCksumSum.name: rlOspfExternLsaCksumSum
rlOspfExternLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit sum of the LS checksums of the external link state advertisements contained in the link state database. This sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in a router's link state database and to compare the link state database of two routers. The value should be treated as unsigned when comparing two sums of checksums.

rlOspfTOSSupport.name: rlOspfTOSSupport
rlOspfTOSSupport.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix F.1.2 Optional TOS support
rlOspfTOSSupport.description: The router's support for type-of-service routing. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfOriginateNewLsas.name: rlOspfOriginateNewLsas
rlOspfOriginateNewLsas.description: The number of new link state advertisements that have been originated. This number is incremented each time the router originates a new LSA. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

rlOspfRxNewLsas.name: rlOspfRxNewLsas
rlOspfRxNewLsas.description: The number of link state advertisements received that are determined to be new instantiations. This number does not include newer instantiations of self-originated link state advertisements. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

rlOspfExtLsdbLimit.name: rlOspfExtLsdbLimit
rlOspfExtLsdbLimit.description: The maximum number of non-default AS-external LSAs entries that can be stored in the link state database. If the value is -1, then there is no limit. When the number of non-default AS-external LSAs in a router's link state database reaches rlOspfExtLsdbLimit, the router enters overflow state. The router never holds more than rlOspfExtLsdbLimit non-default AS-external LSAs in its database. OspfExtLsdbLimit MUST be set identically in all routers attached to the OSPF backbone and/or any regular OSPF area (i.e., OSPF stub areas and NSSAs are excluded). This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfMulticastExtensions.name: rlOspfMulticastExtensions
rlOspfMulticastExtensions.description: A bit mask indicating whether the router is forwarding IP multicast (Class D) datagrams based on the algorithms defined in the multicast extensions to OSPF. Bit 0, if set, indicates that the router can forward IP multicast datagrams in the router's directly attached areas (called intra-area multicast routing). Bit 1, if set, indicates that the router can forward IP multicast datagrams between OSPF areas (called inter-area multicast routing). Bit 2, if set, indicates that the router can forward IP multicast datagrams between Autonomous Systems (called inter-AS multicast routing). Only certain combinations of bit settings are allowed, namely: 0 (no multicast forwarding is enabled), 1 (intra-area multicasting only), 3 (intra-area and inter-area multicasting), 5 (intra-area and inter-AS multicasting), and 7 (multicasting everywhere). By default, no multicast forwarding is enabled. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfExitOverflowInterval.name: rlOspfExitOverflowInterval
rlOspfExitOverflowInterval.description: The number of seconds that, after entering OverflowState, a router will attempt to leave OverflowState. This allows the router to again originate non-default AS-external LSAs. When set to 0, the router will not leave overflow state until restarted. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfDemandExtensions.name: rlOspfDemandExtensions
rlOspfDemandExtensions.reference: Extending OSPF to Support Demand Circuits
rlOspfDemandExtensions.description: The router's support for demand routing. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfRFC1583Compatibility.name: rlOspfRFC1583Compatibility
rlOspfRFC1583Compatibility.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 16.4.1 External path preferences
rlOspfRFC1583Compatibility.description: Indicates metrics used to choose among multiple AS-external LSAs. When RFC1583Compatibility is set to enabled, only cost will be used when choosing among multiple AS-external LSAs advertising the same destination. When RFC1583Compatibility is set to disabled, preference will be driven first by type of path using cost only to break ties. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfOpaqueLsaSupport.name: rlOspfOpaqueLsaSupport
rlOspfOpaqueLsaSupport.description: The router's support for Opaque LSA types.

rlOspfReferenceBandwidth.name: rlOspfReferenceBandwidth
rlOspfReferenceBandwidth.description: Reference bandwidth in kilobits/second for calculating default interface metrics. The default value is 100,000 KBPS (100 MBPS). This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfRestartSupport.name: rlOspfRestartSupport
rlOspfRestartSupport.description: The router's support for OSPF graceful restart. Options include: no restart support, only planned restarts, or both planned and unplanned restarts. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfRestartInterval.name: rlOspfRestartInterval
rlOspfRestartInterval.description: Configured OSPF graceful restart timeout interval. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfRestartStrictLsaChecking.name: rlOspfRestartStrictLsaChecking
rlOspfRestartStrictLsaChecking.description: Indicates if strict LSA checking is enabled for graceful restart. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfRestartStatus.name: rlOspfRestartStatus
rlOspfRestartStatus.description: Current status of OSPF graceful restart.

rlOspfRestartAge.name: rlOspfRestartAge
rlOspfRestartAge.description: Remaining time in current OSPF graceful restart interval.

rlOspfRestartExitReason.name: rlOspfRestartExitReason
rlOspfRestartExitReason.description: Describes the outcome of the last attempt at a graceful restart. If the value is 'none', no restart has yet been attempted. If the value is 'inProgress', a restart attempt is currently underway.

rlOspfAsLsaCount.name: rlOspfAsLsaCount
rlOspfAsLsaCount.description: The number of AS-scope link state advertisements in the AS-scope link state database.

rlOspfAsLsaCksumSum.name: rlOspfAsLsaCksumSum
rlOspfAsLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit unsigned sum of the LS checksums of the AS link state advertisements contained in the AS-scope link state database. This sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in a router's AS-scope link state database, and to compare the AS-scope link state database of two routers.

rlOspfStubRouterSupport.name: rlOspfStubRouterSupport
rlOspfStubRouterSupport.description: The router's support for stub router functionality.

rlOspfStubRouterAdvertisement.name: rlOspfStubRouterAdvertisement
rlOspfStubRouterAdvertisement.description: This object controls the advertisement of stub router LSAs by the router. The value doNotAdvertise will result in the advertisement of a standard router LSA and is the default value. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfDiscontinuityTime.name: rlOspfDiscontinuityTime
rlOspfDiscontinuityTime.description: The value of sysUpTime on the most recent occasion at which any one of this MIB's counters suffered a discontinuity. If no such discontinuities have occurred since the last re-initialization of the local management subsystem, then this object contains a zero value.

rlOspfGeneralGroupStatus.name: rlOspfGeneralGroupStatus
rlOspfGeneralGroupStatus.description: This variable displays the status of the en- try. Setting it to 'invalid' has the effect of rendering it inoperative. The internal effect (row removal) is implementation dependent.

rlOspfLogAdjacencyChanges.name: rlOspfLogAdjacencyChanges
rlOspfLogAdjacencyChanges.description: Configure the router to send a syslog message when an OSPF neighbor goes up or down. detail sends a syslog message for each state change, not just when a neighbor goes up or down

rlOspfPassiveInterface.name: rlOspfPassiveInterface
rlOspfPassiveInterface.description: A flag to note whether to disable sending OSPF routing updates on all OSPF IP interfaces.

rlOspfDefaultMetric.name: rlOspfDefaultMetric
rlOspfDefaultMetric.description: A default metric helps solve the problem of redistributing routes with incompatible metrics. Whenever metrics do not convert, using a default metric provides a reasonable substitute and enables the redistribution to proceed.

rlOspfMaximumRedistPrefixNum.name: rlOspfMaximumRedistPrefixNum
rlOspfMaximumRedistPrefixNum.description: Specifies the maximum number of IP prefixes that can be redistributed into OSPF.

rlOspfMaximumRedistPrefixThreshold.name: rlOspfMaximumRedistPrefixThreshold
rlOspfMaximumRedistPrefixThreshold.description: Threshold value, as a percentage, at which a warning message should be generated.

rlOspfMaximumRedistPrefixWarningOnly.name: rlOspfMaximumRedistPrefixWarningOnly
rlOspfMaximumRedistPrefixWarningOnly.description: Causes a warning message to be logged when the number of prefixes defined by the maximum argumenthas been exceeded. Additional redistribution is not prevented.

rlOspfOperStatus.name: rlOspfOperStatus
rlOspfOperStatus.description: The current operational state of the OSPF in the router.

rlOspfNextRouterId.name: rlOspfNextRouterId
rlOspfNextRouterId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the of router in the Autonomous System after restart. By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this should default to the value of one of the router's IP interface addresses.

rlOspfRouterIdType.name: rlOspfRouterIdType
rlOspfRouterIdType.description: Type of router identifier - default value or manually set by user.

rlOspfNextRouterIdType.name: rlOspfNextRouterIdType
rlOspfNextRouterIdType.description: Type of router identifier after restart - default value or manually set by user.

rlOspfASBdrRtrActualStatus.name: rlOspfASBdrRtrActualStatus
rlOspfASBdrRtrActualStatus.description: A flag to note whether this router is an Autonomous System Border Router. Note: rlOspfASBdrRtrStatus field is the configuration while this filed is the actual ASBR status

rlOspfCalcMaxDelay.name: rlOspfCalcMaxDelay
rlOspfCalcMaxDelay.description: The maximum delay before the Routing Table is recalculated following a change to the Link State Database. (Recalculation is delayed to reduce the frequency of recalculations of the Routing Table). This parameter has units of milliseconds. A value of 0 indicates that a routing calculation will immediately follow an update to the database.

rlOspfRteMaxEqCostPaths.name: rlOspfRteMaxEqCostPaths
rlOspfRteMaxEqCostPaths.description: The maximum number of equal cost paths that are stored for each destination in the Routing Table.

rlOspfAreaTable.name: rlOspfAreaTable
rlOspfAreaTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 6 The Area Data Structure
rlOspfAreaTable.description: Information describing the configured parameters and cumulative statistics of the router's attached areas. The interfaces and virtual links are configured as part of these areas. Area 0.0.0.0, by definition, is the backbone area.

rlOspfAreaEntry.name: rlOspfAreaEntry
rlOspfAreaEntry.description: Information describing the configured parameters and cumulative statistics of one of the router's attached areas. The interfaces and virtual links are configured as part of these areas. Area 0.0.0.0, by definition, is the backbone area. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfAreaProcessId.name: rlOspfAreaProcessId
rlOspfAreaProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfAreaId.name: rlOspfAreaId
rlOspfAreaId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an area. Area ID 0.0.0.0 is used for the OSPF backbone.

rlOspfAuthType.name: rlOspfAuthType
rlOspfAuthType.description: The authentication type specified for an area.

rlOspfImportAsExtern.name: rlOspfImportAsExtern
rlOspfImportAsExtern.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfImportAsExtern.description: Indicates if an area is a stub area, NSSA, or standard area. Type-5 AS-external LSAs and type-11 Opaque LSAs are not imported into stub areas or NSSAs. NSSAs import AS-external data as type-7 LSAs

rlOspfSpfRuns.name: rlOspfSpfRuns
rlOspfSpfRuns.description: The number of times that the intra-area route table has been calculated using this area's link state database. This is typically done using Dijkstra's algorithm. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

rlOspfAreaBdrRtrCount.name: rlOspfAreaBdrRtrCount
rlOspfAreaBdrRtrCount.description: The total number of Area Border Routers reachable within this area. This is initially zero and is calculated in each Shortest Path First (SPF) pass.

rlOspfAsBdrRtrCount.name: rlOspfAsBdrRtrCount
rlOspfAsBdrRtrCount.description: The total number of Autonomous System Border Routers reachable within this area. This is initially zero and is calculated in each SPF pass.

rlOspfAreaLsaCount.name: rlOspfAreaLsaCount
rlOspfAreaLsaCount.description: The total number of link state advertisements in this area's link state database, excluding AS-external LSAs.

rlOspfAreaLsaCksumSum.name: rlOspfAreaLsaCksumSum
rlOspfAreaLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit sum of the link state advertisements' LS checksums contained in this area's link state database. This sum excludes external (LS type-5) link state advertisements. The sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in a router's link state database, and to compare the link state database of two routers. The value should be treated as unsigned when comparing two sums of checksums.

rlOspfAreaSummary.name: rlOspfAreaSummary
rlOspfAreaSummary.description: The variable ospfAreaSummary controls the import of summary LSAs into stub and NSSA areas. It has no effect on other areas. If it is noAreaSummary, the router will not originate summary LSAs into the stub or NSSA area. It will rely entirely on its default route. If it is sendAreaSummary, the router will both summarize and propagate summary LSAs.

rlOspfAreaStatus.name: rlOspfAreaStatus
rlOspfAreaStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorRole.name: rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorRole
rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorRole.description: Indicates an NSSA border router's ability to perform NSSA translation of type-7 LSAs into type-5 LSAs.

rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorState.name: rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorState
rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorState.description: Indicates if and how an NSSA border router is performing NSSA translation of type-7 LSAs into type-5 LSAs. When this object is set to enabled, the NSSA Border router's OspfAreaNssaExtTranslatorRole has been set to always. When this object is set to elected, a candidate NSSA Border router is Translating type-7 LSAs into type-5. When this object is set to disabled, a candidate NSSA border router is NOT translating type-7 LSAs into type-5.

rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorStabilityInterva.name: rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorStabilityInterval
rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorStabilityInterva.description: The number of seconds after an elected translator determines its services are no longer required, that it should continue to perform its translation duties.

rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorEvents.name: rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorEvents
rlOspfAreaNssaTranslatorEvents.description: Indicates the number of translator state changes that have occurred since the last boot-up. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

rlOspfAreaAdminStat.name: rlOspfAreaAdminStat
rlOspfAreaAdminStat.description: The OSPF Area's administrative status. The value formed on the area, and the in- terfaces associated with the area. The value 'disabled' denotes that the area is external to OSPF.

rlOspfAreaOperStatus.name: rlOspfAreaOperStatus
rlOspfAreaOperStatus.description: The current operational state of the OSPF Area.

rlOspfAreaFilterPrefixListIn.name: rlOspfAreaFilterPrefixListIn
rlOspfAreaFilterPrefixListIn.description: The prefix list is applied to prefixes advertised to the specified area from other areas.

rlOspfAreaFilterPrefixListOut.name: rlOspfAreaFilterPrefixListOut
rlOspfAreaFilterPrefixListOut.description: The prefix list is applied to prefixes advertised out of the specified area to other areas.

rlOspfStubAreaTable.name: rlOspfStubAreaTable
rlOspfStubAreaTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2, Area Parameters
rlOspfStubAreaTable.description: The set of metrics that will be advertised by a default Area Border Router into a stub area.

rlOspfStubAreaEntry.name: rlOspfStubAreaEntry
rlOspfStubAreaEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2, Area Parameters
rlOspfStubAreaEntry.description: The metric for a given Type of Service that will be advertised by a default Area Border Router into a stub area. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfStubProcessId.name: rlOspfStubProcessId
rlOspfStubProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfStubAreaId.name: rlOspfStubAreaId
rlOspfStubAreaId.description: The 32-bit identifier for the stub area. On creation, this can be derived from the instance.

rlOspfStubTOS.name: rlOspfStubTOS
rlOspfStubTOS.description: The Type of Service associated with the metric. On creation, this can be derived from the instance.

rlOspfStubMetric.name: rlOspfStubMetric
rlOspfStubMetric.description: The metric value applied at the indicated Type of Service. By default, this equals the least metric at the Type of Service among the interfaces to other areas.

rlOspfStubStatus.name: rlOspfStubStatus
rlOspfStubStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

rlOspfStubMetricType.name: rlOspfStubMetricType
rlOspfStubMetricType.description: This variable displays the type of metric advertised as a default route.

rlOspfLsdbTable.name: rlOspfLsdbTable
rlOspfLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
rlOspfLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's link state database (LSDB). The LSDB contains the link state advertisements from throughout the areas that the device is attached to.

rlOspfLsdbProcessId.name: rlOspfLsdbProcessId
rlOspfLsdbProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfLsdbAreaId.name: rlOspfLsdbAreaId
rlOspfLsdbAreaId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfLsdbAreaId.description: The 32-bit identifier of the area from which the LSA was received.

rlOspfLsdbType.name: rlOspfLsdbType
rlOspfLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
rlOspfLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertisement format. Note: External link state advertisements are permitted for backward compatibility, but should be displayed in the ospfAsLsdbTable rather than here.

rlOspfLsdbLsid.name: rlOspfLsdbLsid
rlOspfLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
rlOspfLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing either a Router ID or an IP address; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

rlOspfLsdbRouterId.name: rlOspfLsdbRouterId
rlOspfLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
rlOspfLsdbRouterId.description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

rlOspfLsdbSequence.name: rlOspfLsdbSequence
rlOspfLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
rlOspfLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It starts with the value '80000001'h, or -'7FFFFFFF'h, and increments until '7FFFFFFF'h. Thus, a typical sequence number will be very negative. It is used to detect old and duplicate Link State Advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number, the more recent the advertisement.

rlOspfLsdbAge.name: rlOspfLsdbAge
rlOspfLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state advertisement in seconds.

rlOspfLsdbChecksum.name: rlOspfLsdbChecksum
rlOspfLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connectionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

rlOspfLsdbAdvertisement.name: rlOspfLsdbAdvertisement
rlOspfLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
rlOspfLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire link state advertisement, including its header. Note that for variable length LSAs, SNMP agents may not be able to return the largest string size.

rlOspfAreaRangeTable.name: rlOspfAreaRangeTable
rlOspfAreaRangeTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaRangeTable.description: The Address Range Table acts as an adjunct to the Area Table. It describes those Address Range Summaries that are configured to be propagated from an Area to reduce the amount of information about it that is known beyond its borders. It contains a set of IP address ranges specified by an IP address/IP network mask pair. For example, class B address range of X.X.X.X with a network mask of 255.255.0.0 includes all IP addresses from X.X.0.0 to X.X.255.255. Note that this table is obsoleted and is replaced by the Area Aggregate Table.

rlOspfAreaRangeEntry.name: rlOspfAreaRangeEntry
rlOspfAreaRangeEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaRangeEntry.description: A single area address range. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfAreaRangeProcessId.name: rlOspfAreaRangeProcessId
rlOspfAreaRangeProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfAreaRangeAreaId.name: rlOspfAreaRangeAreaId
rlOspfAreaRangeAreaId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaRangeAreaId.description: The area that the address range is to be found within.

rlOspfAreaRangeNet.name: rlOspfAreaRangeNet
rlOspfAreaRangeNet.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaRangeNet.description: The IP address of the net or subnet indicated by the range.

rlOspfAreaRangeMask.name: rlOspfAreaRangeMask
rlOspfAreaRangeMask.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaRangeMask.description: The subnet mask that pertains to the net or subnet.

rlOspfAreaRangeStatus.name: rlOspfAreaRangeStatus
rlOspfAreaRangeStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

rlOspfAreaRangeEffect.name: rlOspfAreaRangeEffect
rlOspfAreaRangeEffect.description: Subnets subsumed by ranges either trigger the advertisement of the indicated summary (advertiseMatching) or result in the subnet's not being advertised at all outside the area.

rlOspfHostTable.name: rlOspfHostTable
rlOspfHostTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host route parameters
rlOspfHostTable.description: The Host/Metric Table indicates what hosts are directly attached to the router, what metrics and types of service should be advertised for them, and what areas they are found within.

rlOspfHostEntry.name: rlOspfHostEntry
rlOspfHostEntry.description: A metric to be advertised, for a given type of service, when a given host is reachable. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfHostProcessId.name: rlOspfHostProcessId
rlOspfHostProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfHostIpAddress.name: rlOspfHostIpAddress
rlOspfHostIpAddress.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host route parameters
rlOspfHostIpAddress.description: The IP address of the host.

rlOspfHostTOS.name: rlOspfHostTOS
rlOspfHostTOS.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host route parameters
rlOspfHostTOS.description: The Type of Service of the route being configured.

rlOspfHostMetric.name: rlOspfHostMetric
rlOspfHostMetric.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host route parameters

rlOspfHostStatus.name: rlOspfHostStatus
rlOspfHostStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

rlOspfHostAreaID.name: rlOspfHostAreaID
rlOspfHostAreaID.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host parameters
rlOspfHostAreaID.description: The OSPF area to which the host belongs. Deprecated by ospfHostCfgAreaID.

rlOspfHostCfgAreaID.name: rlOspfHostCfgAreaID
rlOspfHostCfgAreaID.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host parameters
rlOspfHostCfgAreaID.description: To configure the OSPF area to which the host belongs.

rlOspfIfTable.name: rlOspfIfTable
rlOspfIfTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Router interface parameters
rlOspfIfTable.description: The OSPF Interface Table describes the interfaces from the viewpoint of OSPF. It augments the ipAddrTable with OSPF specific information.

rlOspfIfEntry.name: rlOspfIfEntry
rlOspfIfEntry.description: The OSPF interface entry describes one interface from the viewpoint of OSPF. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfIfProcessId.name: rlOspfIfProcessId
rlOspfIfProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfIfIpAddress.name: rlOspfIfIpAddress
rlOspfIfIpAddress.description: The IP address of this OSPF interface.

rlOspfAddressLessIf.name: rlOspfAddressLessIf
rlOspfAddressLessIf.description: For the purpose of easing the instancing of addressed and addressless interfaces; this variable takes the value 0 on interfaces with IP addresses and the corresponding value of ifIndex for interfaces having no IP address.

rlOspfIfAreaId.name: rlOspfIfAreaId
rlOspfIfAreaId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the area to which the interface connects. Area ID 0.0.0.0 is used for the OSPF backbone.

rlOspfIfType.name: rlOspfIfType
rlOspfIfType.description: The OSPF interface type. By way of a default, this field may be intuited from the corresponding value of ifType. Broadcast LANs, such as Ethernet and IEEE 802.5, take the value 'broadcast', X.25 and similar technologies take the value 'nbma', and links that are definitively point to point take the value 'pointToPoint'.

rlOspfIfAdminStat.name: rlOspfIfAdminStat
rlOspfIfAdminStat.description: The OSPF interface's administrative status. The value formed on the interface, and the interface will be advertised as an internal route to some area. The value 'disabled' denotes that the interface is external to OSPF.

rlOspfIfRtrPriority.name: rlOspfIfRtrPriority
rlOspfIfRtrPriority.description: The priority of this interface. Used in multi-access networks, this field is used in the designated router election algorithm. The value 0 signifies that the router is not eligible to become the designated router on this particular network. In the event of a tie in this value, routers will use their Router ID as a tie breaker.

rlOspfIfTransitDelay.name: rlOspfIfTransitDelay
rlOspfIfTransitDelay.description: The estimated number of seconds it takes to transmit a link state update packet over this interface. Note that the minimal value SHOULD be 1 second.

rlOspfIfRetransInterval.name: rlOspfIfRetransInterval
rlOspfIfRetransInterval.description: The number of seconds between link state advertisement retransmissions, for adjacencies belonging to this interface. This value is also used when retransmitting database description and Link State request packets. Note that minimal value SHOULD be 1 second.

rlOspfIfHelloInterval.name: rlOspfIfHelloInterval
rlOspfIfHelloInterval.description: The length of time, in seconds, between the Hello packets that the router sends on the interface. This value must be the same for all routers attached to a common network.

rlOspfIfRtrDeadInterval.name: rlOspfIfRtrDeadInterval
rlOspfIfRtrDeadInterval.description: The number of seconds that a router's Hello packets have not been seen before its neighbors declare the router down. This should be some multiple of the Hello interval. This value must be the same for all routers attached to a common network.

rlOspfIfPollInterval.name: rlOspfIfPollInterval
rlOspfIfPollInterval.description: The larger time interval, in seconds, between the Hello packets sent to an inactive non-broadcast multi-access neighbor.

rlOspfIfDesignatedRouter.name: rlOspfIfDesignatedRouter
rlOspfIfDesignatedRouter.description: The IP address of the designated router.

rlOspfIfBackupDesignatedRouter.name: rlOspfIfBackupDesignatedRouter
rlOspfIfBackupDesignatedRouter.description: The IP address of the backup designated router.

rlOspfIfEvents.name: rlOspfIfEvents
rlOspfIfEvents.description: The number of times this OSPF interface has changed its state or an error has occurred. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

rlOspfIfAuthKey.name: rlOspfIfAuthKey
rlOspfIfAuthKey.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 9 The Interface Data Structure
rlOspfIfAuthKey.description: The cleartext password used as an OSPF authentication key when simplePassword security is enabled. This object does not access any OSPF cryptogaphic (e.g., MD5) authentication key under any circumstance. If the key length is shorter than 8 octets, the agent will left adjust and zero fill to 8 octets. Unauthenticated interfaces need no authentication key, and simple password authentication cannot use a key of more than 8 octets. Note that the use of simplePassword authentication is NOT recommended when there is concern regarding attack upon the OSPF system. SimplePassword authentication is only sufficient to protect against accidental misconfigurations because it re-uses cleartext passwords [RFC1704]. When read, rlOspfIfAuthKey always returns an octet string of length zero.

rlOspfIfStatus.name: rlOspfIfStatus
rlOspfIfStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

rlOspfIfMulticastForwarding.name: rlOspfIfMulticastForwarding
rlOspfIfMulticastForwarding.description: The way multicasts should be forwarded on this interface: not forwarded, forwarded as data link multicasts, or forwarded as data link unicasts. Data link multicasting is not meaningful on point-to-point and NBMA interfaces, and setting ospfMulticastForwarding to 0 effectively disables all multicast forwarding.

rlOspfIfDemand.name: rlOspfIfDemand
rlOspfIfDemand.description: Indicates whether Demand OSPF procedures (hello suppression to FULL neighbors and setting the DoNotAge flag on propagated LSAs) should be performed on this interface.

rlOspfIfAuthType.name: rlOspfIfAuthType
rlOspfIfAuthType.description: The authentication type specified for an interface. Note that this object can be used to engage in significant attacks against an OSPF router.

rlOspfIfLsaCount.name: rlOspfIfLsaCount
rlOspfIfLsaCount.description: The total number of link-local link state advertisements in this interface's link-local link state database.

rlOspfIfLsaCksumSum.name: rlOspfIfLsaCksumSum
rlOspfIfLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit unsigned sum of the Link State Advertisements' LS checksums contained in this interface's link-local link state database. The sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in the interface's link state database and to compare the interface link state database of routers attached to the same subnet.

rlOspfIfDesignatedRouterId.name: rlOspfIfDesignatedRouterId
rlOspfIfDesignatedRouterId.description: The Router ID of the designated router.

rlOspfIfBackupDesignatedRouterId.name: rlOspfIfBackupDesignatedRouterId
rlOspfIfBackupDesignatedRouterId.description: The Router ID of the backup designated router.

rlOspfIfOperStatus.name: rlOspfIfOperStatus
rlOspfIfOperStatus.description: The current operational state of the OSPF interface.

rlOspfIfAuthKeyChain.name: rlOspfIfAuthKeyChain
rlOspfIfAuthKeyChain.description: The name of the authentication key-chain configured on this interface. The key-chain is a reference to which set of secret keys are to be accessed in order to determine which secret key string to use. The key chain name is not the secret key string password and can also be used in other routing protocols, such as RIP and ISIS.

rlOspfIfPassive.name: rlOspfIfPassive
rlOspfIfPassive.description: Indicates whether this interface is a passive interface. If set to TRUE, we suppress HELLO packets sent on and received from this interface. We will therefore advertise this interface in our LSAs but not run OSPF protocol over it.

rlOspfIfLsaRefreshIntvl.name: rlOspfIfLsaRefreshIntvl
rlOspfIfLsaRefreshIntvl.description: Self-originated LSAs are periodically reflooded into the routing domain, to add to the robustness of the OSPF protocol. This value determines the interval between refreshes of LSAs that are only flooded over this interface, for example type-9 opaque LSAs, and is defaulted to the OSPF standard default of 1800 seconds (30 minutes).

rlOspfIfFastHelloMultiplier.name: rlOspfIfFastHelloMultiplier
rlOspfIfFastHelloMultiplier.description: The number of Hellos that should be sent within 1 second when using Fast Hellos on this interface. This value does not have to be same for all routers attached to a common network, but it is advisable. Fast Hellos are configured using ospfPmIfRtrDeadInterval.

rlOspfIfMtuIgnore.name: rlOspfIfMtuIgnore
rlOspfIfMtuIgnore.description: This object controls whether DC-OSPF checks the MTU size on incoming Database Description packets. By default, if the received MTU size in a DB Description packet is higher than the MTU size configured on the incoming interface, the OSPF adjacency will not be established. If the interface is tunneled over, say, an MPLS network, then the administrator may not know the maximum MTU size and so can tell DC-OSPF to ignore the MTU size on incoming DB description packets.

rlOspfIfNameLookup.name: rlOspfIfNameLookup
rlOspfIfNameLookup.description: A flag to note whether to look up Domain Name System (DNS) names for use in all OSPF show EXEC command displays.

rlOspfIfIfIndex.name: rlOspfIfIfIndex
rlOspfIfIfIndex.description: A 32-bit index identifying this interface, or zero if no index value is known. For interfaces having no IP Address this field is automatically set to the value of the address-less interface index field.

rlOspfIfActualAuthType.name: rlOspfIfActualAuthType
rlOspfIfActualAuthType.description: The actual authentication type specified for an interface.

rlOspfIfMetricTable.name: rlOspfIfMetricTable
rlOspfIfMetricTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Router interface parameters
rlOspfIfMetricTable.description: The Metric Table describes the metrics to be advertised for a specified interface at the various types of service. As such, this table is an adjunct of the OSPF Interface Table. Types of service, as defined by RFC 791, have the ability to request low delay, high bandwidth, or reliable linkage. For the purposes of this specification, the measure of bandwidth: Metric = referenceBandwidth / ifSpeed is the default value. The default reference bandwidth is 10^8. For multiple link interfaces, note that ifSpeed is the sum of the individual link speeds. This yields a number having the following typical values: Network Type/bit rate Metric >= 100 MBPS 1 Ethernet/802.3 10 E1 48 T1 (ESF) 65 64 KBPS 1562 56 KBPS 1785 19.2 KBPS 5208 9.6 KBPS 10416 Routes that are not specified use the default (TOS 0) metric. Note that the default reference bandwidth can be configured using the general group object ospfReferenceBandwidth.

rlOspfIfMetricEntry.name: rlOspfIfMetricEntry
rlOspfIfMetricEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Router interface parameters
rlOspfIfMetricEntry.description: A particular TOS metric for a non-virtual interface identified by the interface index. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfIfMetricProcessId.name: rlOspfIfMetricProcessId
rlOspfIfMetricProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfIfMetricIpAddress.name: rlOspfIfMetricIpAddress
rlOspfIfMetricIpAddress.description: The IP address of this OSPF interface. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

rlOspfIfMetricAddressLessIf.name: rlOspfIfMetricAddressLessIf
rlOspfIfMetricAddressLessIf.description: For the purpose of easing the instancing of addressed and addressless interfaces; this variable takes the value 0 on interfaces with IP addresses and the value of ifIndex for interfaces having no IP address. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

rlOspfIfMetricTOS.name: rlOspfIfMetricTOS
rlOspfIfMetricTOS.description: The Type of Service metric being referenced. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

rlOspfIfMetricValue.name: rlOspfIfMetricValue
rlOspfIfMetricValue.description: The metric of using this Type of Service on this interface. The default value of the TOS 0 metric is 10^8 / ifSpeed.

rlOspfIfMetricStatus.name: rlOspfIfMetricStatus
rlOspfIfMetricStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

rlOspfVirtIfTable.name: rlOspfVirtIfTable
rlOspfVirtIfTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.4 Virtual link parameters
rlOspfVirtIfTable.description: Information about this router's virtual interfaces that the OSPF Process is configured to carry on.

rlOspfVirtIfEntry.name: rlOspfVirtIfEntry
rlOspfVirtIfEntry.description: Information about a single virtual interface. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfVirtIfProcessId.name: rlOspfVirtIfProcessId
rlOspfVirtIfProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfVirtIfAreaId.name: rlOspfVirtIfAreaId
rlOspfVirtIfAreaId.description: The transit area that the virtual link traverses. By definition, this is not 0.0.0.0.

rlOspfVirtIfNeighbor.name: rlOspfVirtIfNeighbor
rlOspfVirtIfNeighbor.description: The Router ID of the virtual neighbor.

rlOspfVirtIfTransitDelay.name: rlOspfVirtIfTransitDelay
rlOspfVirtIfTransitDelay.description: The estimated number of seconds it takes to transmit a Link State update packet over this interface. Note that the minimal value SHOULD be 1 second.

rlOspfVirtIfRetransInterval.name: rlOspfVirtIfRetransInterval
rlOspfVirtIfRetransInterval.description: The number of seconds between link state avertisement retransmissions, for adjacencies belonging to this interface. This value is also used when retransmitting database description and Link State request packets. This value should be well over the expected round-trip time. Note that the minimal value SHOULD be 1 second.

rlOspfVirtIfHelloInterval.name: rlOspfVirtIfHelloInterval
rlOspfVirtIfHelloInterval.description: The length of time, in seconds, between the Hello packets that the router sends on the interface. This value must be the same for the virtual neighbor.

rlOspfVirtIfRtrDeadInterval.name: rlOspfVirtIfRtrDeadInterval
rlOspfVirtIfRtrDeadInterval.description: The number of seconds that a router's Hello packets have not been seen before its neighbors declare the router down. This should be some multiple of the Hello interval. This value must be the same for the virtual neighbor.

rlOspfVirtIfEvents.name: rlOspfVirtIfEvents
rlOspfVirtIfEvents.description: The number of state changes or error events on this virtual link. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

rlOspfVirtIfAuthKey.name: rlOspfVirtIfAuthKey
rlOspfVirtIfAuthKey.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 9 The Interface Data Structure
rlOspfVirtIfAuthKey.description: The cleartext password used as an OSPF authentication key when simplePassword security is enabled. This object does not access any OSPF cryptogaphic (e.g., MD5) authentication key under any circumstance. If the key length is shorter than 8 octets, the agent will left adjust and zero fill to 8 octets. Unauthenticated interfaces need no authentication key, and simple password authentication cannot use a key of more than 8 octets. Note that the use of simplePassword authentication is NOT recommended when there is concern regarding attack upon the OSPF system. SimplePassword authentication is only sufficient to protect against accidental misconfigurations because it re-uses cleartext passwords. [RFC1704] When read, rlOspfIfAuthKey always returns an octet string of length zero.

rlOspfVirtIfStatus.name: rlOspfVirtIfStatus
rlOspfVirtIfStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

rlOspfVirtIfAuthType.name: rlOspfVirtIfAuthType
rlOspfVirtIfAuthType.description: The authentication type specified for a virtual interface. Note that this object can be used to engage in significant attacks against an OSPF router.

rlOspfVirtIfLsaCount.name: rlOspfVirtIfLsaCount
rlOspfVirtIfLsaCount.description: The total number of link-local link state advertisements in this virtual interface's link-local link state database.

rlOspfVirtIfLsaCksumSum.name: rlOspfVirtIfLsaCksumSum
rlOspfVirtIfLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit unsigned sum of the link state advertisements' LS checksums contained in this virtual interface's link-local link state database. The sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in the virtual interface's link state database, and to compare the virtual interface link state database of the virtual neighbors.

rlOspfVirtIfAuthKeyChain.name: rlOspfVirtIfAuthKeyChain
rlOspfVirtIfAuthKeyChain.description: The name of the authentication key-chain configured on this interface. The key-chain is a reference to which set of secret keys are to be accessed in order to determine which secret key string to use. The key chain name is not the secret key string password and can also be used in other routing protocols, such as RIP and ISIS.

rlOspfVirtIfAdminStatus.name: rlOspfVirtIfAdminStatus
rlOspfVirtIfAdminStatus.description: The desired administrative state of this virtual interface.

rlOspfVirtIfOperStatus.name: rlOspfVirtIfOperStatus
rlOspfVirtIfOperStatus.description: The current operational state of this virtual interface.

rlOspfVirtIfIndex.name: rlOspfVirtIfIndex
rlOspfVirtIfIndex.description: The local index assigned by the OSPF Process to this OSPF virtual interface.

rlOspfVirtIfActualAuthType.name: rlOspfVirtIfActualAuthType
rlOspfVirtIfActualAuthType.description: The actual authentication type specified for a virtual interface.

rlOspfNbrTable.name: rlOspfNbrTable
rlOspfNbrTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 10 The Neighbor Data Structure
rlOspfNbrTable.description: A table describing all non-virtual neighbors in the locality of the OSPF router.

rlOspfNbrEntry.name: rlOspfNbrEntry
rlOspfNbrEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 10 The Neighbor Data Structure
rlOspfNbrEntry.description: The information regarding a single neighbor. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfNbrProcessId.name: rlOspfNbrProcessId
rlOspfNbrProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfNbrIpAddr.name: rlOspfNbrIpAddr
rlOspfNbrIpAddr.description: The IP address this neighbor is using in its IP source address. Note that, on addressless links, this will not be 0.0.0.0 but the address of another of the neighbor's interfaces.

rlOspfNbrAddressLessIndex.name: rlOspfNbrAddressLessIndex
rlOspfNbrAddressLessIndex.description: On an interface having an IP address, zero. On addressless interfaces, the corresponding value of ifIndex in the Internet Standard MIB. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

rlOspfNbrRtrId.name: rlOspfNbrRtrId
rlOspfNbrRtrId.description: A 32-bit integer (represented as a type IpAddress) uniquely identifying the neighboring router in the Autonomous System.

rlOspfNbrOptions.name: rlOspfNbrOptions
rlOspfNbrOptions.description: A bit mask corresponding to the neighbor's options field. Bit 0, if set, indicates that the system will operate on Type of Service metrics other than TOS 0. If zero, the neighbor will ignore all metrics except the TOS 0 metric. Bit 1, if set, indicates that the associated area accepts and operates on external information; if zero, it is a stub area. Bit 2, if set, indicates that the system is capable of routing IP multicast datagrams, that is that it implements the multicast extensions to OSPF. Bit 3, if set, indicates that the associated area is an NSSA. These areas are capable of carrying type-7 external advertisements, which are translated into type-5 external advertisements at NSSA borders.

rlOspfNbrPriority.name: rlOspfNbrPriority
rlOspfNbrPriority.description: The priority of this neighbor in the designated router election algorithm. The value 0 signifies that the neighbor is not eligible to become the designated router on this particular network.

rlOspfNbrState.name: rlOspfNbrState
rlOspfNbrState.description: The state of the relationship with this neighbor.

rlOspfNbrEvents.name: rlOspfNbrEvents
rlOspfNbrEvents.description: The number of times this neighbor relationship has changed state or an error has occurred. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

rlOspfNbrLsRetransQLen.name: rlOspfNbrLsRetransQLen
rlOspfNbrLsRetransQLen.description: The current length of the retransmission queue.

rlOspfNbmaNbrStatus.name: rlOspfNbmaNbrStatus
rlOspfNbmaNbrStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

rlOspfNbmaNbrPermanence.name: rlOspfNbmaNbrPermanence
rlOspfNbmaNbrPermanence.description: This variable displays the status of the entry; 'dynamic' and 'permanent' refer to how the neighbor became known.

rlOspfNbrHelloSuppressed.name: rlOspfNbrHelloSuppressed
rlOspfNbrHelloSuppressed.description: Indicates whether Hellos are being suppressed to the neighbor.

rlOspfNbrRestartHelperStatus.name: rlOspfNbrRestartHelperStatus
rlOspfNbrRestartHelperStatus.description: Indicates whether the router is acting as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.

rlOspfNbrRestartHelperAge.name: rlOspfNbrRestartHelperAge
rlOspfNbrRestartHelperAge.description: Remaining time in current OSPF graceful restart interval, if the router is acting as a restart helper for the neighbor.

rlOspfNbrRestartHelperExitReason.name: rlOspfNbrRestartHelperExitReason
rlOspfNbrRestartHelperExitReason.description: Describes the outcome of the last attempt at acting as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.

rlOspfNbrDeadTime.name: rlOspfNbrDeadTime
rlOspfNbrDeadTime.description: The time remaining in seconds within which we need to receive a hello packet from the neighbor or we declare the adjacency down. If fast hellos area in use, this value is always set to 1. If the oper_status is down or ospfPmNbrState is DOWN, then the value is set to zero and the field is not valid.

rlOspfNbrAreaId.name: rlOspfNbrAreaId
rlOspfNbrAreaId.description: The area to which the neighbor belongs. If the oper_status is down, then this value is set to zero and the field is not valid.

rlOspfNbrIfIndex.name: rlOspfNbrIfIndex
rlOspfNbrIfIndex.description: The interface index to whitch the neighbor is connected.

rlOspfNbrIfIpAddr.name: rlOspfNbrIfIpAddr
rlOspfNbrIfIpAddr.description: The interface IP address to whitch the neighbor is connected.

rlOspfVirtNbrTable.name: rlOspfVirtNbrTable
rlOspfVirtNbrTable.description: This table describes all virtual neighbors. Since virtual links are configured in the Virtual Interface Table, this table is read-only.

rlOspfVirtNbrProcessId.name: rlOspfVirtNbrProcessId
rlOspfVirtNbrProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfVirtNbrRtrId.name: rlOspfVirtNbrRtrId
rlOspfVirtNbrRtrId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the neighboring router in the Autonomous System.

rlOspfVirtNbrIpAddr.name: rlOspfVirtNbrIpAddr
rlOspfVirtNbrIpAddr.description: The IP address this virtual neighbor is using.

rlOspfVirtNbrOptions.name: rlOspfVirtNbrOptions
rlOspfVirtNbrOptions.description: A bit mask corresponding to the neighbor's options field. Bit 1, if set, indicates that the system will operate on Type of Service metrics other than TOS 0. If zero, the neighbor will ignore all metrics except the TOS 0 metric. Bit 2, if set, indicates that the system is network multicast capable, i.e., that it implements OSPF multicast routing.

rlOspfVirtNbrState.name: rlOspfVirtNbrState
rlOspfVirtNbrState.description: The state of the virtual neighbor relationship.

rlOspfVirtNbrEvents.name: rlOspfVirtNbrEvents
rlOspfVirtNbrEvents.description: The number of times this virtual link has changed its state or an error has occurred. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

rlOspfVirtNbrLsRetransQLen.name: rlOspfVirtNbrLsRetransQLen
rlOspfVirtNbrLsRetransQLen.description: The current length of the retransmission queue.

rlOspfVirtNbrHelloSuppressed.name: rlOspfVirtNbrHelloSuppressed
rlOspfVirtNbrHelloSuppressed.description: Indicates whether Hellos are being suppressed to the neighbor.

rlOspfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatus.name: rlOspfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatus
rlOspfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatus.description: Indicates whether the router is acting as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.

rlOspfVirtNbrRestartHelperAge.name: rlOspfVirtNbrRestartHelperAge
rlOspfVirtNbrRestartHelperAge.description: Remaining time in current OSPF graceful restart interval, if the router is acting as a restart helper for the neighbor.

rlOspfVirtNbrRestartHelperExitReason.name: rlOspfVirtNbrRestartHelperExitReason
rlOspfVirtNbrRestartHelperExitReason.description: Describes the outcome of the last attempt at acting as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.

rlOspfVirtNbrDeadTime.name: rlOspfVirtNbrDeadTime
rlOspfVirtNbrDeadTime.description: The time remaining in seconds within which we need to receive a hello packet from the neighbor or we declare the adjacency down. If fast hellos area in use, this value is always set to 1. If the oper_status is down or ospfPmVirtNbrState is DOWN, then the value is set to zero and the field is not valid.

rlOspfExtLsdbTable.name: rlOspfExtLsdbTable
rlOspfExtLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
rlOspfExtLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's external LSA link state database. This table is identical to the OSPF LSDB Table in format, but contains only external link state advertisements. The purpose is to allow external LSAs to be displayed once for the router rather than once in each non-stub area. Note that external LSAs are also in the AS-scope link state database.

rlOspfExtLsdbProcessId.name: rlOspfExtLsdbProcessId
rlOspfExtLsdbProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfExtLsdbType.name: rlOspfExtLsdbType
rlOspfExtLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
rlOspfExtLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertisement format.

rlOspfExtLsdbLsid.name: rlOspfExtLsdbLsid
rlOspfExtLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
rlOspfExtLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing either a Router ID or an IP address; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

rlOspfExtLsdbRouterId.name: rlOspfExtLsdbRouterId
rlOspfExtLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
rlOspfExtLsdbRouterId.description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

rlOspfExtLsdbSequence.name: rlOspfExtLsdbSequence
rlOspfExtLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
rlOspfExtLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It starts with the value '80000001'h, or -'7FFFFFFF'h, and increments until '7FFFFFFF'h. Thus, a typical sequence number will be very negative. It is used to detect old and duplicate link state advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number, the more recent the advertisement.

rlOspfExtLsdbAge.name: rlOspfExtLsdbAge
rlOspfExtLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state advertisement in seconds.

rlOspfExtLsdbChecksum.name: rlOspfExtLsdbChecksum
rlOspfExtLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connectionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

rlOspfExtLsdbAdvertisement.name: rlOspfExtLsdbAdvertisement
rlOspfExtLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
rlOspfExtLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire link state advertisement, including its header.

rlOspfAreaAggregateTable.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateTable
rlOspfAreaAggregateTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaAggregateTable.description: The Area Aggregate Table acts as an adjunct to the Area Table. It describes those address aggregates that are configured to be propagated from an area. Its purpose is to reduce the amount of information that is known beyond an Area's borders. It contains a set of IP address ranges specified by an IP address/IP network mask pair. For example, a class B address range of X.X.X.X with a network mask of 255.255.0.0 includes all IP addresses from X.X.0.0 to X.X.255.255. Note that if ranges are configured such that one range subsumes another range (e.g., 10.0.0.0 mask 255.0.0.0 and 10.1.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0), the most specific match is the preferred one.

rlOspfAreaAggregateEntry.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateEntry
rlOspfAreaAggregateEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaAggregateEntry.description: A single area aggregate entry. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

rlOspfAreaAggregateProcessId.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateProcessId
rlOspfAreaAggregateProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfAreaAggregateAreaID.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateAreaID
rlOspfAreaAggregateAreaID.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaAggregateAreaID.description: The area within which the address aggregate is to be found.

rlOspfAreaAggregateLsdbType.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateLsdbType
rlOspfAreaAggregateLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
rlOspfAreaAggregateLsdbType.description: The type of the address aggregate. This field specifies the Lsdb type that this address aggregate applies to.

rlOspfAreaAggregateNet.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateNet
rlOspfAreaAggregateNet.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaAggregateNet.description: The IP address of the net or subnet indicated by the range.

rlOspfAreaAggregateMask.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateMask
rlOspfAreaAggregateMask.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfAreaAggregateMask.description: The subnet mask that pertains to the net or subnet.

rlOspfAreaAggregateStatus.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateStatus
rlOspfAreaAggregateStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

rlOspfAreaAggregateEffect.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateEffect
rlOspfAreaAggregateEffect.description: Subnets subsumed by ranges either trigger the advertisement of the indicated aggregate (advertiseMatching) or result in the subnet's not being advertised at all outside the area.

rlOspfAreaAggregateExtRouteTag.name: rlOspfAreaAggregateExtRouteTag
rlOspfAreaAggregateExtRouteTag.description: External route tag to be included in NSSA (type-7) LSAs.

rlOspfLocalLsdbTable.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbTable
rlOspfLocalLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements and The OSPF Opaque LSA Option
rlOspfLocalLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's link-local link state database for non-virtual links. This table is identical to the OSPF LSDB Table in format, but contains only link-local Link State Advertisements for non-virtual links. The purpose is to allow link-local LSAs to be displayed for each non-virtual interface. This table is implemented to support type-9 LSAs that are defined in 'The OSPF Opaque LSA Option'.

rlOspfLocalLsdbIpAddress.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbIpAddress
rlOspfLocalLsdbIpAddress.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Interface parameters
rlOspfLocalLsdbIpAddress.description: The IP address of the interface from which the LSA was received if the interface is numbered.

rlOspfLocalLsdbAddressLessIf.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbAddressLessIf
rlOspfLocalLsdbAddressLessIf.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Interface parameters
rlOspfLocalLsdbAddressLessIf.description: The interface index of the interface from which the LSA was received if the interface is unnumbered.

rlOspfLocalLsdbType.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbType
rlOspfLocalLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
rlOspfLocalLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertisement format.

rlOspfLocalLsdbLsid.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbLsid
rlOspfLocalLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
rlOspfLocalLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing a 32-bit identifier in IP address format; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

rlOspfLocalLsdbRouterId.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbRouterId
rlOspfLocalLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
rlOspfLocalLsdbRouterId.description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

rlOspfLocalLsdbSequence.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbSequence
rlOspfLocalLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
rlOspfLocalLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It starts with the value '80000001'h, or -'7FFFFFFF'h, and increments until '7FFFFFFF'h. Thus, a typical sequence number will be very negative. It is used to detect old and duplicate link state advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number, the more recent the advertisement.

rlOspfLocalLsdbAge.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbAge
rlOspfLocalLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state advertisement in seconds.

rlOspfLocalLsdbChecksum.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbChecksum
rlOspfLocalLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connectionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

rlOspfLocalLsdbAdvertisement.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbAdvertisement
rlOspfLocalLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
rlOspfLocalLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire link state advertisement, including its header. Note that for variable length LSAs, SNMP agents may not be able to return the largest string size.

rlOspfLocalLsdbAreaId.name: rlOspfLocalLsdbAreaId
rlOspfLocalLsdbAreaId.description: The OSPF area in which the link belongs.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbTable.name: rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbTable
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements and The OSPF Opaque LSA Option
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's link-local link state database for virtual links. This table is identical to the OSPF LSDB Table in format, but contains only link-local Link State Advertisements for virtual links. The purpose is to allow link-local LSAs to be displayed for each virtual interface. This table is implemented to support type-9 LSAs that are defined in 'The OSPF Opaque LSA Option'.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbTransitArea.name: rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbTransitArea
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbTransitArea.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Interface parameters
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbTransitArea.description: The transit area that the virtual link traverses. By definition, this is not 0.0.0.0.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbNeighbor.name: rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbNeighbor
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbNeighbor.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Interface parameters
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbNeighbor.description: The Router ID of the virtual neighbor.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbType.name: rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbType
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertisement format.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbLsid.name: rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbLsid
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing a 32-bit identifier in IP address format; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbRouterId.name: rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbRouterId
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbRouterId.description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbSequence.name: rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbSequence
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It starts with the value '80000001'h, or -'7FFFFFFF'h, and increments until '7FFFFFFF'h. Thus, a typical sequence number will be very negative. It is used to detect old and duplicate link state advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number, the more recent the advertisement.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state advertisement in seconds.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbChecksum.name: rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbChecksum
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connectionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbAdvertisement.name: rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbAdvertisement
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements. Note that for variable length LSAs, SNMP agents may not be able to return the largest string size.
rlOspfVirtLocalLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire link state advertisement, including its header.

rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfErrors.name: rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfErrors
rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfErrors.description: A bit mask indicating enable SNMP notifications for OSPF errors. Bit 0, if set, for authenticationFailure trap. enables only the ospfIfFailure trap. Allows SNMP notifications to be sent when a packet has been received on a nonvirtual interface from a neighbor router whose authentication key or authentication type conflicts with the authentication key or authentication type of this router. Bit 1, if set, for badPacket trap. enables only the ospfIfRxBadPacket trap. Allows SNMP notifications to be sent when an OSPF packet that has not been parsed has been received on a nonvirtual interface. Bit 2, if set, for configError trap. enables only the ospfIfConfigError trap. Sends SNMP notifications when a packet has been received in a nonvirtual interface from a neighbor router whose configuration parameters conflict with the configuration parameters of this router. Bit 3, if set, for virtAuthenticationFailure trap. enables only the ospfVirtIfFailure trap. Allows SNMP notifications to be sent when a packet has been received on a virtual interface from a neighbor router whose authentication key or authentication type conflicts with the authentication key or authentication type of this router. Bit 4, if set, for virtBadPacket trap. enables only the ospfVirtIfRxBadPacket trap. Allows SNMP notifications to be sent when an OSPF packet that has not been parsed has been received on a virtual interface. Bit 5, if set, for virtConfigError trap. enables only the ospfVirtIfConfigError trap. Sends SNMP notifications when a packet has been received in a virtual interface from a neighbor router whose configuration parameters conflict with the configuration parameters of this router.

rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfLsa.name: rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfLsa
rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfLsa.description: A bit mask indicating enable SNMP notifications for OSPF LSA Bit 0, if set, for maxAgeLsa trap. enable the ospfMaxAgeLsa trap. Bit 1, if set, for originateLsa trap. enable the ospfOriginateLsa trap. When the originateLsa trap is enabled, it will not be invoked for simple LSA refreshes that take place every 30 minutes or when an LSA has reached its maximum age and is being flushed.

rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfRateLimitSeconds.name: rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfRateLimitSeconds
rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfRateLimitSeconds.description: Sets the rate limit window size, in seconds. A number from 2 to 60. The default value is 10.

rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfRateLimitTrapNumber.name: rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfRateLimitTrapNumber
rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfRateLimitTrapNumber.description: Sets the maximum number of traps sent during the window time. A number from 0 to 300. The default number is 7.

rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfTransmit.name: rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfTransmit
rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfTransmit.description: A bit mask indicating enable SNMP notifications for OSPF transmit Bit 0, if set, for packets trap. enables only the ospfTxRetransmit trap. Allows SNMP notifications to be sent when an OSPF packet has been re-sent on a nonvirtual interface. Bit 1, if set, for virtPackets trap. enables only the ospfVirtTxRetransmit trap. Allows SNMP notifications to be sent when an OSPF packet has been re-sent on a virtual interface.

rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfStateChange.name: rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfStateChange
rlOspfEnableTrapsOspfStateChange.description: A bit mask indicating enable SNMP notifications for OSPF State Change. Bit 0, if set, for ifStateChange trap. only the ospfIfStateChange trap. Sends SNMP notifications when there has been a change in the state of a non-virtual OSPF interface. Bit 1, if set, for neighborStateChange trap. enables only the ospfNbrStateChange trap. Sends SNMP notifications when there has been a change in the state of a non-virtual OSPF neighbor. Bit 2, if set, for ospfVirtIfStateChange trap. only the ospfVirtIfStateChange trap. Sends SNMP notifications when there has been a change in the state of a virtual OSPF interface. Bit 3, if set, for ospfVirtNbrStateChange trap. enables only the ospfVirtNbrStateChange trap. Sends SNMP notifications when there has been a change in the state of a virtual OSPF neighbor.

rlOspfBrRouterEntry.name: rlOspfBrRouterEntry
rlOspfBrRouterEntry.description: A single entry from Router LSA.

rlOspfBrRouterProcessId.name: rlOspfBrRouterProcessId
rlOspfBrRouterProcessId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an OSPF process.

rlOspfBrRouterAreaId.name: rlOspfBrRouterAreaId
rlOspfBrRouterAreaId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
rlOspfBrRouterAreaId.description: The 32 bit identifier of the Route Area.

rlOspfBrRouterRouterId.name: rlOspfBrRouterRouterId
rlOspfBrRouterRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
rlOspfBrRouterRouterId.description: The 32 bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

rlOspfBrRouterOutIf.name: rlOspfBrRouterOutIf
rlOspfBrRouterOutIf.description: The outgoing interface toward the destination.

rlOspfBrRouterRouteType.name: rlOspfBrRouterRouteType
rlOspfBrRouterRouteType.description: intra is intra-area route. inter is inter-area route.

rlOspfBrRouterRouterType.name: rlOspfBrRouterRouterType
rlOspfBrRouterRouterType.description: The border router type: ABR, ASBR or both ABR and ASBR.
